quiz.title: Unit 11: International Microeconomics (Quiz 4)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Trade Balance, Exchange Rate Systems, & Trade Institutions
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Balance of Payments, Fixed vs. Flexible Exchange Rates, Trade Deficits/Surpluses, Trade Agreements

questions.question: When Country A has a comparative advantage in producing wheat and Country B has a comparative advantage in producing textiles, both countries can benefit from trade by:
options: Country A specializing in wheat and Country B specializing in textiles, then trading
Country A producing both goods but exporting wheat at a higher price
Country B imposing tariffs on wheat to protect its domestic producers
Both countries producing both goods but trading the surpluses
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage leads to gains from trade when countries specialize in producing goods where they have lower opportunity costs and trade for other goods.

questions.question: In the balance of payments, the current account includes:
options: Trade in goods and services, investment income, and unilateral transfers
Foreign direct investment and portfolio investment flows
Changes in official reserve assets held by the central bank
Government borrowing and lending from international organizations
questions.explanation: The current account records trade in goods/services (balance of trade), investment income (interest, dividends), and unilateral transfers (foreign aid, remittances).

questions.question: Under a fixed exchange rate system, if a country faces persistent balance of payments deficits, the central bank must:
options: Sell foreign currency reserves to support its currency's value
Allow its currency to depreciate to equilibrium level
Increase domestic interest rates to attract capital inflows
Both A and C are necessary actions
questions.explanation: Under fixed rates, central banks intervene to maintain parity. For deficits: sell foreign reserves (to buy domestic currency) and/or raise interest rates (to attract capital inflows and support currency).

questions.question: A country with a trade surplus (exports > imports) will typically experience:
options: Net capital outflow as it accumulates foreign assets
Net capital inflow as foreigners invest in the country
Appreciation of its currency under flexible exchange rates
Both A and C are likely outcomes
questions.explanation: Trade surplus means net exports > 0. This creates net capital outflow (surplus invested abroad) and under flexible rates, increased demand for currency causes appreciation.

questions.question: The most-favored-nation (MFN) principle in international trade requires that:
options: Any trade concession granted to one WTO member must be extended to all members
Countries must eliminate all tariffs on agricultural products
Developing countries receive preferential treatment in trade agreements
Trade disputes are resolved through binding arbitration
questions.explanation: MFN is a core WTO principle preventing discrimination among trading partners. Trade advantages given to one member must be given to all WTO members.

questions.question: If the U.S. dollar appreciates against the euro, U.S. imports from the Eurozone will likely:
options: Increase because European goods become cheaper in dollar terms
Decrease because European goods become more expensive in dollar terms
Remain unchanged because prices are fixed in contracts
Decrease only if demand for European goods is price elastic
questions.explanation: Dollar appreciation means each dollar buys more euros. Euro-priced goods become cheaper when converted to dollars, making them more attractive to U.S. consumers.

questions.question: Which of the following represents a non-tariff barrier to trade?
options: A 10% ad valorem tariff on imported automobiles
Import quotas limiting textile imports to 1 million units annually
Technical standards requiring specific safety features on electronics
Both B and C are non-tariff barriers
questions.explanation: Non-tariff barriers include quotas (quantitative restrictions) and technical standards/regulations that disproportionately affect imports. Tariffs are price-based barriers.

questions.question: Under a flexible exchange rate system, a country with higher inflation than its trading partners will experience:
options: Currency depreciation to maintain purchasing power parity
Currency appreciation as interest rates rise to combat inflation
Increased exports as domestic goods become relatively cheaper
No automatic exchange rate adjustment
questions.explanation: Higher inflation reduces purchasing power domestically. Under flexible rates, the currency depreciates to restore purchasing power parity (PPP) with trading partners.

questions.question: The 'J-curve effect' describes the phenomenon where:
options: Currency depreciation initially worsens the trade balance before improving it
Trade liberalization initially increases imports before boosting exports
Economic growth initially increases trade deficits before creating surpluses
Tariff reductions initially harm domestic producers before benefiting consumers
questions.explanation: The J-curve: currency depreciation makes imports immediately more expensive (worsening trade balance in short run) but over time, as export quantities rise and import quantities fall (if Marshall-Lerner holds), trade balance improves.

questions.question: A country with a current account deficit must have:
options: A financial/capital account surplus of equal magnitude
Decreasing foreign exchange reserves
A trade surplus in goods and services
Net capital outflow to finance the deficit
questions.explanation: Balance of payments must balance: Current Account + Financial Account = 0. Therefore, a current account deficit (negative) must be matched by a financial account surplus (positive) of equal size.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent understanding of balance of payments, exchange rate systems, and trade institutions.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review exchange rate mechanisms and balance of payments accounting.
scoreMessages.50: Needs practice with trade balance analysis and exchange rate effects.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on: comparative advantage → specialization; BOP must balance; flexible rates adjust automatically; fixed rates require intervention.
